results.title: The Horse whisperer
results.creator_credit: Robert Redford, Patrick Markey and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: Robert Redford directs himself for the first time in this romantic drama adapted from the best-seller by Nicholas Evans. Teenager Grace and her friend Judith go horseback riding in upstate New York on a winter morning. After a devastating accident, Judith and her horse are killed, while Grace and her horse, Pilgrim, are seriously injured, the frightening incident leaving them both traumatised. Desperate to help, Grace’s mother puts her busy life on hold and travels west with Grace and Pilgrim to see a horse trainer with a special gift. Once there she discovers that his extraordinary gift with horses also touches the lives of those around him. Cast includes Robert Redford, Kristin Scott Thomas, Scarlett Johnasson, Sam Neill, Chris Cooper and Dianne Wiest.

results.title: What do you think about getting what you're after
results.creator_credit: Gundrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “What Do You Think”.
This film invites discussion of whether, in business competition, one’s standards of fair play should be lowered. The question revolves around two young women who seek the same job. While one has already applied for the position and is reasonably sure of getting it, she lessens her chances by telling the other that applications are still being accepted. A third woman questions the first’s “softness” and the audience is asked to judge. No. 6 in the series.

results.title: Edward Albee's A Delicate Balance
results.creator_credit: Edward Albee, Tony Richardson, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Listening carefully to the sharp and witty dialogue is the key to engaging with this dramatic play adapted for the screen. Produced originally on the New York stage by Richard Barr and Clinton Wilder, adapted here for the screen by the playwright Edward Albee. Set in suburban New England, a well-to-do older couple (Katharine Hepburn and Paul Scofield) live their lives in a staid familiarity that can only set in with a long-term relationship. The delicate balance that is their marriage is rocked only by the presence of the wife’s alcoholic sister Claire (Kate Reid) and their melancholic daughter (Lee Remick) dealing with yet another failed marriage. Two friends (Joseph Cotton and Betsy Blair) turn up wanting to stay for good but as a group they work through this to get back the ‘balance’. A Pulitzer Prize winning play, this screen version deals with the notions of family, friendship and love, directed by Tony Richardson.

results.title: Having your say
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “What Do You Think”.
Are there circumstances in which one group may justifiably deny to another a chance to have its say at a public meeting when a question concerning both is at issue? This problem comes to the fore in a clash between a teenage group and a community center committee. The young people are accused of destructive behavior and are, without a hearing, denied the use of the center. In retaliation they hire a hall to publicly voice their protest. The committee feels it too should be heard at the meeting. The question is left to the film audience.

results.title: Choosing a leader
results.creator_credit: Julia Murphy, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “What Do You Think”.
An open-ended discussion film for teenaged groups dealing with the problem of choosing a leader. The story concerns a group of boys and girls hiking in the woods, facing the possibility of being lost. One boy, always highly admired because of his athletic prowess, wants to take one direction; another boy, with considerable logic on his side, wants to take the other. What are the factors the group must take into consideration in deciding whose leadership to choose? The question is left with the film audience.

results.title: Rhinoceros
results.creator_credit: Tom O'Horgan, Ely Landau, Ely Landau Organization and American Express Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
A satirical comedy about bored and alcoholic office worker Stanley (Gene Wilder) and his friend John (Zero Mostel) who bare witness to a strange ‘illness’ in which fellow human beings slowly turn into Rhinos. A film rendition of Eugene Ionesco’s play, part of Theater of the Absurd, “Rhinoceros” looks to explore the themes of conformity in society and keeping-up-appearances. Will Stanley be able to resist becoming one of the herd and maintain his individuality? This low budget film has some compelling performances, particularly that of Mostel when he makes his transition to the animal kingdom and some wacky black comedy situations, such as a stampede of Rhinos (that are left to the imagination to see) that take out the stairs of the office leaving Stanley and his workmates stranded. Stanley has his own particularly simple attitude: “I’m indifferent to life, so I take a few drinks and then it doesn’t bother me anymore.” Cast includes Karen Black, Joe Silver, Robert Weil.

results.title: Being different
results.creator_credit: Julia Murphy, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “What Do You Think”.
Departing from the norm, from accepting patterns of dress or behaviour, can bring down on the head of an erring teenager the unqualified disapproval of his gang. Is this attitude valid? The film cites the case of a thirteen year old boy who has developed an interest in collecting butterflies - a hobby that his friends laugh at. Should he pursue his genuine interest, or should he conform?

results.title: The House on the waterfall
results.brief_description: Acclaimed by the American institute of Architects as the best American building built in the last 125 years, Fallingwater, built by Frank Lloyd Wright has attracted since its construction in 1936 ongoing international accolades. The home built as a summer residence for a family was designed in direct response to it’s environment. The building is sited over a waterfall using mostly counter-levered platforms. The documentary extrapolates on the building method (with archival footage) and details with interviews the materials used and intellectual ideals that directed the external and interior functionalist aesthetics. The documentary observes the home throughout the seasons to illustrate the depth of the Lloyd Wright’s design and his consideration for a place to be lived in and shared with a changing environment. Narrated by Bingo O’Malley.
